We're talking with Aimee Mann about the release, 40 years ago, of ""Sergeant Pepper."" You're listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
And here's an e-mail we got from Rosemary(ph) in Baltimore.
I have four young children, although there's a sticker in the baby book for first steps and first word, I had to make up my own sticker for first time listening to ""Sergeant Pepper's.

Thanks for taking my call.
Sure.
First of all, before I get into my comments on ""Sergeant Pepper,"" I wanted just to say thank you to Aimee for appearing.
I followed her since she was ""Until Tuesday"" and ""That's Just The Way You Are"" is one of my favorite songs in the world.
Oh, thank you.
I - ""Sergeant Pepper's,"" for me, it - you know, I was born in 1964, so it was part of the soundscape of my life.
My family that listen to the radio all throughout the '60s, especially the late '60s FM radio, where FM radio was completely different than it is today.
And it wasn't until I inherited by aunt's records when she went into disco in like '70s that I really realized what a great album it was.
I was 13 at the time.

But I spent hours looking at the cover, and the touchstone of my kind of musical understanding was that album and probably the compilation albums, the red and the blue albums that the Beatles released later.
But it was really part of the soundscape of the late '60s that you couldn't escape it if you were growing up then.
Yes.
Yeah.
That's certainly inescapable.
Bruce, thanks very much.
Thank you.
